Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 03:23PM Ukkate wrote: I went for a diagnostic mammo because I had a lump!  It was quite "feelable" but the radiologist said "Nothing to worry about - let's follow up in 6 months"  So I went away thinking all was okay and my Primary Doctor (who is actually a nurse practioner) got the films from my Mammo and called me to suggest I go get a second opinion.  So two months after that orignal mammo, I went to a breast specialist (still not really worried) and on that same day, had a U/S and a biopsy and was called the very next day to say I had cancer!  If I had waited the 6 months I don't know what would've happened.  The MRI showed that I had two lumps in the same breast and a sizeable area of DCIS.  So I'm wondering about the point of having a mammo!  I had my first screening mammo a year ago when I turned 40 - but my breasts are really dense.  And even after having cancer and a mastectomy, it's still only recommended that I have another mammo in a year.  I would be much happier if I could go straight to an MRI.
Posts.Title: Mammogram/Radiologist did not see cancer - anyone else? Del5 Calameda

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 09:04AM Ukkate wrote: Hi Tracy, My kids are the same age as yours and I also have a 13 year old daughter.  I was diagnosed in March 3 days before my 42nd birthday.  I remember things seemed to move really slowly for me at the time, I needed an MRI, then another U/S, then another MRI and biopsy....and I had a mastectomy on April 10th.  Looking back, things actually did move pretty quickly!  Anyway - I'm going thru chemo right now and this has probably been the hardest on my kids as I'm so tired and I don't have my hair etc, but other than that, life hasn't changed too much for them.  It's just kinda been "business as usual"  I made sure to talk to the kids teachers and let them know what was going on, and we obviously told them that I was going to be sick at times, and unable to do stuff at times (after the mastectomy) but I would go through my treatment and I would be okay at the end of it (of course, we don't know that part for sure, but my odds are good with stage 1).  Anyway - I worked right up to the day of my mastectomy and that really helped me.  I am DYING to get back to work now but chemo has kicked my butt... You will feel much better once you get some information and you start putting your "plan" together. Hugs
Posts.Title: 43, Mother of 2 Young Boys and Scared! Tr8cyg DC197

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2013 07:07AM Ukkate wrote: I got diagnosed on a Thursday and was back at work on Friday. I had to take time of here and there for MRIs bit pretty much worked like a dog til my mastectomy and then had to take time off. So my office appreciated the time and work I did before all the surgery and chemo started
Posts.Title: work the day after phone call of biopsy results lovewins lovewins

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2013 11:11AM Ukkate wrote: I wanted to follow up on this. I was supposed to start a promotion right at the time I was diagnosed but obviously had to delay it. That was some of my desire to keep working as hard as I could. Anyway, took 10 days off for the mastectomy and then missed a few weeks when I started chemo due to side effects. I declined the long term disability and have been consistently at work since starting taxol - even scheduling chemo at 2pm so I could work half a day first. I just found out that I'm not getting my promotion :(. So I'm almost kicking myself for busting my butt so much - and I have three kids at home too - youngest is 6. Anyway, I guess I'm trying to say do what feels best for you. (And I guess I just needed to vent). Kate
Posts.Title: work the day after phone call of biopsy results lovewins lovewins

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2013 02:21PM Ukkate wrote: Karyn, I was in your shoes just over a month ago. I was advised to get an MRI as the mammo didn't detect the tumor and the MRI showed up areas of DCIS along with the tumor so I went from expecting a lumpectomy, to getting a mastectomy on my left breast just 10 days ago. But lymph node was clear so ill have chemo and a year of hercepten but no rads. I also have a 6 year old You seem to have a great attitude xx

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2013 04:29PM Ukkate wrote: My 6 year old knows I have cancer and knows I went to hospital but all in all the atmosphere is quite cheery in the house and he's been enjoying the sleepovers he's had the past two weekends while my husband has to work and I've been recovering. I'm sure it'll be a bit more scary for him once I lose my hair. I also have a 13 year old daughter and an 11 year old son.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 09:27AM Ukkate wrote: I had some fat grafting done in February and I had my port removed then, even though I had 4 more Herceptin sessions to go.  But the first Herceptin after getting the port removed was a nightmare.  They stuck me 5 times and even blew out a vein.  Then the one they found collapsed once they started the infusion. The last few times have been a bit easier, I am hydrating myself much more during the week and as soon as I get to the clinic, I wrap my arm in a warm blanket. One more to go!!!!  I only had it removed then because I didn't want to take any more time off work to go back to hospital after I was done with herceptin.  And I was under general so it seemed easiest..... Port scar is a bit gnarly though :(
Posts.Title: When / or Did you have your Port Removed after Chemo? laurie2025 Spookiesmom
